text: so I've been traveling for about 10
years now I've been lactose intolerant
for all those years three of them I've
been vegan for and about six months I
was gluten free so it's safe to say that
I know quite a bit about traveling with
allergies food restrictions dietary
requirements as a vegan etc so these are
some of the best tips and tricks that
I've learned and I've managed to
continue my travels with I've managed to
thrive get my nutrients you know I'm
still here so I've succeeded so far so
one the first things that you're gonna
want to do is to research your region
the world is very very big and certain
parts of it are a lot more accommodating
to your diet than others for example as
a vegan there are certain countries and
parts of the world that it's very very
difficult to find food and just because
their local food is nothing close to

a lot more difficult and a lot trickier
so I'm gonna want to make sure that the

more suitable to the dietary
restrictions that I have and the foods

being a vegetarian it's really not that
tricky to travel most places in the
world there are vegetarian options the
real issue is the vegans because we
don't eat egg or milk most like 90
percent of vegetarian options have dairy

where it gets really really tricky
because even if it doesn't have meat is

that that is the case that the

a lot on like beef product on cows when

a vegan like when I first started

a lot easier like they hardly ever used
area a little bit in Indian cuisine

was just buy a couple of boxes of things
and just keep it in my hotel room or in

that you know what's in your food is to
rent places with kitchens now this was
really really important when I had
friends with allergies that I traveled
with because it was just very difficult
to constantly be eating out and having
cheat meals because it's never ever
gonna be perfect so having a kitchen you
can guarantee you know exactly what

that you are renting from like the

you're going to local grocery stores but

it's safe for you you know you can eat

every language that I learned are I
don't eat meat I don't eat dairy and
memorize it because I'm gonna be

to memorize it
there are allergy cards I'm allergic to
this I cannot eat this do not put this
in my food and that is translated in the

are visiting you can then hand that over
to the waitstaff so they can read and
understand and they can also take it
back to the cooks so they can understand
as well and I usually like to have
multiple of these printed out so if it
gets lost or if the cook ends up keeping
them it's not a big deal another option
if you don't want to print out physical
cards or have physical cards with you is
Google Translate you can just literally
show them your translation and they'll
be able to read it as well another
little tip is to don't trust the menus
menus are not 100% accurate all the time
sometimes vegetarian means chicken is
okay in some countries so I will always
